thread.title: Chaney on D'Andre Swift: 'I can't wait to get him in here'
thread.title_full: Chaney on D'Andre Swift: 'I can't wait to get him in here'

title: Chaney on D'Andre Swift: 'I can't wait to get him in here'
text:
Manage Chaney on D'Andre Swift: 'I can't wait to get him in here' Georgia offensive coordinator Jim Chaney believes he has something special to work with in 2017 UGA signee D'Andre Swift.   
ATHENS, Ga. -- Georgia entered the 2017 recruiting cycling knowing -- not hoping or thinking, but knowing -- that it had to get its hands on a big-time running back. 
Nick Chubb and Sony Michel appeared to be on their way out and the Bulldogs needed to add more than just depth at the position. They needed the next great Bulldog ball carrier. 
All signs point to D'Andre Swift being that guy. Swift and fellow Pennsylvanian Mark Webb were the first to send in their National Letters of Intent on Wednesday, giving UGA coaches the ability to discuss them publicly. When Georgia offensive coordinator Jim Chaney was asked about him, he didn't hold back. (Photo: Tony Morano, 247Sports) 
“His ball skills are unbelievable as far as a running back goes," Chaney said of Swift. "His ability to detach (move out of the box) and do things that other can’t do at that position will be fun to utilize as we watch him grow in our offense. I can’t wait to get him in here this summer and see what he can do." 
It's tough to fault the long-time assistant. There's a lot to like about the nation's 33rd overall prospect according to the industry-generated 247Sports Composite. He had an incredible week of practice at the U.S. Army All-American game and played well in the game. 
He was also the MVP of the North American Championship just last weekend with over 100 yards rushing and a pair of scores. Not a member? For a limited time, buy one month of Dawgs247 VIP, get two months FREE! 
As a matter of fact, Swift's willingness to play the game every time he gets the chance is one of the things Chaney and the UGA staff likes most about him. 
"The one thing about this young man is he loves to compete," Chaney said. "You give him an all-star game, he’s going to play in it. You bring him to a camp, he’s going to compete. He’s not going to be a five-star kid out there watching. So you absolutely love his competitive spirit. He comes from that. Mom and dad are that way. He’s that way. So I love that. He’s walking into the door expecting to play and is probably going to try and do it.” 
While the likelihood is high that Swift, at worst, has a rock-solid UGA career, it won't be easy to see the field early on. Chubb and Michel stand in his way as do talented rising sophomores Brian Herrien and Elijah Holyfield . 
But as Chaney said, there are things the 5-foot-9, 220-pound playmaker can do that most tailbacks can't. But before he does any of that, he'll have the challenge of moving over 700 miles away from home and into a completely different climate. 
"It’ll be fun to watch them play," Chaney said with a laugh. "They’ll enjoy this Georgia heat that first month.” 
(What's next for the Bulldogs? Make sure you're in the loop -- take a few moments to sign up for our FREE Bulldogs Newsletter! ) Author
